title: Open RDP from command line: Feature Request
author: nasarmahmood
body_snippet:
<!-- Feature Request -->

I run a script which shows me the disk usage on all servers in our estate, This allows me to apply action where required, all of this is done through powershell, would be good if i could start mremotng rdp to that server from there also. 

I do already have these servers in mremoteng saved in the config file.

comments.author: harvestmedia
comments.snippet: I would like to start a SSH session from command line too.

comments.author: netserf
comments.snippet: I use putty's feature to directly launch ssh "saved sessions" from command line or launcher. This helps avoid mouse clicks and improves productivity. I hope you can add a command line launching feature to mRemoteNG as well.

comments.author: pedro2555
comments.snippet:
Can you elaborate a bit better, I think this is inline with something I would benefit from myself.

If I understood you correctly, you want to be able to execute mRemoteNG and automatically connect to a specific connection you have on the connection tree.
Either via command line parameters or other setup.

Is this correct?

comments.author: nasarmahmood
comments.snippet:
Hi, yes that's it. So from either a powershell or command line  I could
type something like mremoteng servername

That would then open up that server n mremoteng with the credentials that I
had previously saved.

Regards
Nasar Mahmood

comments.author: netserf
comments.snippet:
I use `putty -load <hostname>` to invoke a new putty session. Not so much from the command line directly, but all the time from the Windows "search programs and files" launcher. Its much faster than the mouse.

For the folder issue, could you use a command like `mremoteng <folder>/<hostname>`? This seems like the natural invocation for a folder/file metaphor.

comments.author: netserf
comments.snippet: I may be getting ahead of myself here, but if this `mremoteng <folder>/<hostname>` format is acceptable, then it would be nice to open multiple sessions at once with `mremoteng <folder1>/<hostname1> <folder2>/<hostname2>`. Would this work?

comments.author: augster2016
comments.snippet: That option would be great! Terminals (4.0.1) currently has that option (start "" "C:\Program Files (x86)\Terminals\Terminals.exe" /favs:%MACHINE_NAME% (where %MACHINE_NAME% is the connection in your favorites that you want Terminals to start)), but Terminals doesn't have some of the more sophisticated mRemoteNG features I really like.
